dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: People think wildlife monitoring is all about trudging through the bush, but actually, it's getting seriously high-tech.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wildlife inspectors in Altyn-Emel National Park captured a striking moment during a spring count of Siberian mountain goats (Siberian ibex) last week. The count took place on April 17, 2025, covering the mountainous areas of Sholak, Degeres, and Matai.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the footage is justâ€¦ it's like a nature documentary. These goats scaling a sheer cliff face, in perfect sync.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using a drone, national park staff managed to film a small herd of mountain goats skillfully scaling a steep cliff face. The powerful and graceful animals moved in perfect synchrony, and the footage had a distinctly cinematic quality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's incredible, they're so powerful and graceful at the same time. And they did this without a single human being nearby to disturb them, you know?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This approach allows researchers to track migration patterns, population numbers, and animal behavior without disturbing the animals with human presence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, that's the beauty of using drones and camera traps for year-round monitoring. You get to see their real behavior, their migration patterns.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Monitoring of the park's wildlife is carried out not only during seasonal surveys but also year-round using camera traps. This approach allows researchers to track migration patterns, population numbers, and animal behavior without disturbing the animals with human presence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And these aren't small animals either. The males can weigh up to 130 kilograms, with those massive horns that can be a meter and a half long.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The animals grow to around 150 centimeters in length and can weigh up to 130 kilograms. Males have distinctive horns that can reach up to 1.5 meters in length, with prominent transverse ridges.

dialogue_turns.text: A meter and a half! That's taller than some people. They're like living monuments on those mountain ridges.

dialogue_turns.text: They really are symbols of that park. You see them on the slopes of Sholak and Matai, especially in the spring when everything is waking up.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Siberian mountain goat is considered one of the symbols of Altyn-Emel. In spring, as nature awakens, the animals become particularly active.
